content:
Diagnosis:	Stage IC1 mucinous ovarian carcinoma

Management:	15 Jan 2024 Primary debulking surgery - Total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy

Histology:	Moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma, capsule breach during surgery, HER2 negative

Current Situation:	Pre cycle 4 carboplatin/paclitaxel

I reviewed [redacted name] today in the gynae-oncology clinic. She is tolerating chemotherapy well overall with no significant toxicities. Her main side effect remains grade 1 peripheral neuropathy affecting her fingertips, which is not impacting daily activities. Her nausea is well controlled with standard antiemetics. She has maintained her weight at 68kg and continues to exercise regularly with daily walks.

Blood results show stable parameters with hemoglobin 115 g/L, neutrophils 2.8, platelets 245. CA125 has normalized at 22 (previously 45 after cycle 2, down from 180 at diagnosis). Performance status remains 0.

On examination today, surgical wounds are well healed with no concerning features. Cardiorespiratory examination is normal.

The plan is to proceed with cycle 4 carboplatin AUC5 and paclitaxel 175mg/m2 today. We will arrange CT chest/abdomen/pelvis after cycle 6 to assess end of treatment response. She will be reviewed again in clinic prior to cycle 5 in three weeks.

primary_cancer.histopathology_status: moderately differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma with capsule breach during surgery

cancer_timeline.value: Primary debulking surgery - Total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, omentectomy

patient_facts.value: Grade 1 peripheral neuropathy affecting fingertips, not impacting daily activities
Well healed surgical wounds with no concerning features

status_updates.value: Stage IC1 ovarian cancer post-surgery, responding well to adjuvant chemotherapy with normalizing tumor markers and good tolerability
Grade 1 peripheral neuropathy and well-controlled nausea
Proceeding with cycle 4 carboplatin AUC5 and paclitaxel 175mg/m2
CT chest/abdomen/pelvis after cycle 6 to assess end of treatment response
Review in clinic prior to cycle 5 in three weeks
